Award.AwardTitle: The International Linguistics Olympiad: Preparing High School Students for the Study of Human Language and Computation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
More than 100 of the world's brightest and most motivated high school students will gather in Pittsburgh in July 2011 for the 9th International Linguistics Olympiad. Unlike math and science Olympiads, which focus on material students have already mastered, linguistics Olympiads introduce new material through logic puzzles in languages unfamiliar to the students. In the course of solving a puzzle, the students can discover something about the grammar or sounds of a language, its conceptual system, its culture, or its historical relationship to other languages. In addition to fostering insight into human linguistic and cultural diversity, this competition fosters meta-linguistic reasoning that is essential for computer science, language technologies, and indeed any career involving analytical problem-solving skills and the ability to present a logical argument supported by data. Because it has been the tradition of linguistics Olympiads to assign half of the score for the written explanation of the answer, the contests also encourage the ability to clearly present a hypothesis and explain how it is supported by the data.

More information and past contest puzzles can be found at: http://www.ioling.org and http://www.naclo.cs.cmu.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carnegie Mellon University hosted the ninth International Linguistics Olympiad (http://www.ioling.org) on July 23 to July 30, 2011.   Linguistics Olympiads introduce high school students to the diversity and intricacy of human language via pencil-and-paper puzzles in languages they don’t know.    In the course of solving the puzzles, the students learn something about a language such as it’s sounds, grammar, poetic meter and rhyme, calendar, or number system.   The contest focuses on skill in pattern recognition, analytical reasoning, and clear, expository writing.   Linguistic Olympiads are intended to make students aware of the field of linguistics before they attend university and also provide them with analytical skills that will be useful to them in any major.  

Twenty-seven teams (102 contestants) from nineteen countries partipated in the ninth IOL.   The participating countries were Australia, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, Estonia, India, Ireland, South Korea, Latvia, Netherlands, Poland, Russia, Singapore, Slovenia, Sweden, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States, and Vietnam.   A complete list of problems, solutions, participants, and awards can be found at http://www.ioling.org/2011/ .  

This grant provided funding for housing and food for one team (four high school students) and one coach from each country as well as for the IOL jury. The contribution from NSF was used for dormitories and administrative costs.
